<p style="margin: 0; font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in">Indicate by check mark whether the registrant is a large accelerated filer,
an accelerated filer, a non-accelerated filer, a smaller reporting company or an emerging growth company.&nbsp;See the definitions
of &#8220;large accelerated filer,&#8221; &#8220;accelerated filer,&#8221; &#8220;smaller reporting company,&#8221; and &#8220;emerging
growth company&#8221; in Rule 12b-2 of the Exchange Act.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0; text-indent: 0.5in"></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0; text-indent: 0.5in">If an emerging growth company, indicate by check mark if the registrant
has elected not to use the extended transition period for complying with any new or revised financial accounting standards provided
pursuant to Section 13(a) of the Exchange Act. [ ]</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0; text-indent: 0.5in">Indicate by check mark whether the registrant has filed a report on and
attestation to its management&#8217;s assessment of the effectiveness of its internal control over financial reporting under Section
404(b) of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act (15 U.S.C. 7262(b)) by the registered public accounting firm that prepared or issued its audit
report. [ ]</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">Indicate by check mark whether the registrant is a shell company (as
defined in Rule 12b-2 of the Exchange Act).&nbsp;&nbsp; [&nbsp; ] Yes&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;[x] No</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">The aggregate market value of the registrant&#8217;s
outstanding common stock held by non-affiliates of the registrant computed by reference to the price at which the common stock
was last sold, as of the last business day of the registrant&#8217;s most recently completed second fiscal quarter was approximately
$7.1 million.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">As of March 16, 2021, the registrant had <b>5,157,344</b> shares of common
stock outstanding.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">The information required by Part III is incorporated
by reference from the registrant&#8217;s definitive proxy statement to be filed with the Commission pursuant to Regulation 14A
within 120 days after the end of the fiscal year covered by this report.</p>

    <td><font style="font-size: 10pt; color: Black"><a href="#a_024">ITEM 10.</a></font></td>
    <td><font style="font-size: 10pt; color: Black"><a href="#a_024">DIRECTORS, EXECUTIVE OFFICERS AND CORPORATE GOVERNANCE</a></font></td>
    <td style="text-align: right"><font style="font-size: 10pt; color: Black"><a href="#a_024">19</a></font></td></tr>
<tr style="vertical-align: top">
    <td><font style="font-size: 10pt; color: Black"><a href="#a_025">ITEM 11.</a></font></td>
    <td><font style="font-size: 10pt; color: Black"><a href="#a_025">EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION</a></font></td>
    <td style="text-align: right"><font style="font-size: 10pt; color: Black"><a href="#a_025">19</a></font></td></tr>
<tr style="vertical-align: top">
    <td><font style="font-size: 10pt; color: Black"><a href="#a_026">ITEM 12.</a></font></td>
    <td><font style="font-size: 10pt; color: Black"><a href="#a_026">SECURITY OWNERSHIP OF CERTAIN BENEFICIAL OWNERS AND MANAGEMENT AND RELATED
    STOCKHOLDER MATTERS</a></font></td>
    <td style="text-align: right"><font style="font-size: 10pt; color: Black"><a href="#a_026">19</a></font></td></tr>
<tr style="vertical-align: top">
    <td><font style="font-size: 10pt; color: Black"><a href="#a_027">ITEM 13.</a></font></td>

<!-- Field: Page; Sequence: 3 -->
    <div style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-bottom: 6pt; border-bottom: Black 4pt solid"><table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse: collapse; width: 100%; font-size: 10pt"><tr style="vertical-align: top; text-align: left"><td style="width: 33%">&nbsp;</td><td style="width: 34%; text-align: center"><!-- Field: Sequence; Type: Arabic; Name: PageNo -->3<!-- Field: /Sequence --></td><td style="width: 33%; text-align: right">&nbsp;</td></tr></table></div>

<p style="margin: 0; font-size: 10pt"><font style="color: Black"><b>FORWARD LOOKING STATEMENTS</b></font></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"><i>This Annual Report on Form 10-K contains certain
&#8220;forward-looking statements&#8221; as such term is defined in Section 27A of the Securities Act of 1933, as amended, Section
21E of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended (the &#8220;Exchange Act&#8221;), and the Private Securities Litigation
Reform Act of 1995. Such forward-looking statements relating to Wilhelmina International, Inc. (together with its subsidiaries
the &#8220;Company&#8221; or &#8220;Wilhelmina&#8221;) are based on the beliefs of the Company&#8217;s management as well as information
currently available to the Company&#8217;s management.&nbsp;When used in this report, the words &#8220;anticipate,&#8221; &#8220;believe,&#8221;
&#8220;estimate,&#8221; &#8220;expect&#8221; and &#8220;intend&#8221; and words or phrases of similar import, as they relate to
the Company or Company management, are intended to identify forward-looking statements.&nbsp;Such forward-looking statements include,
in particular, projections about the Company&#8217;s future results, statements about its plans, strategies, business prospects,
changes and trends in its business and the markets in which it operates. Additionally, statements concerning future matters such
as gross billing levels, revenue levels, expense levels, and other statements regarding matters that are not historical are forward-looking
statements. Management cautions that these forward-looking statements relate to future events or the Company&#8217;s future financial
performance and are subject to business, economic, and other risks and uncertainties, both known and unknown, that may cause actual
results, levels of activity, performance, or achievements of its business or its industry to be materially different from those
expressed or implied by any forward-looking statements. Should any one or more of these risks or uncertainties materialize, or
should any underlying assumptions prove incorrect, actual results may vary materially from those described herein as anticipated,
believed, estimated, expected or intended.&nbsp;The Company does not undertake any obligation to publicly update these forward-looking
statements.&nbsp;As a result, you should not place undue reliance on these forward-looking statements.</i></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0"></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: center; margin: 0"><a name="a_007"></a><b>PART I</b></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"><tr style="vertical-align: top">
<td style="width: 0"></td><td style="width: 1in"><b><a name="a_008"></a>ITEM 1.</b></td><td><i>BUSINESS</i></td></tr></table>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"><b>DESCRIPTION OF THE WILHELMINA BUSINESS</b></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"><b>Overview</b></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">The primary business of Wilhelmina is fashion model
management. These business operations are headquartered in New York City.&nbsp;The Company&#8217;s predecessor was founded in 1967
by Wilhelmina Cooper, a renowned fashion model, and became one of the oldest, best known&nbsp;and largest fashion model management
companies in the world.&nbsp;Since its founding, Wilhelmina has grown to include operations located in Los Angeles, Miami, Chicago,
and London, as well as a network of licensees.&nbsp;Wilhelmina provides traditional, full-service fashion model and talent management
services, specializing in the representation and management of models, entertainers, athletes and other talent, to various clients,
including retailers, designers, advertising agencies, print and electronic media and catalog companies. The Company was incorporated
in the State of Delaware in 1996.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0"><b>Organization and Operating Divisions</b></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">The Company acquired the predecessor companies constituting
its current primary business in 2008. The Company conducts its business through operating divisions and subsidiaries engaged in
fashion model management and other complementary businesses. These business activities are focused on the following key areas:</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"><tr style="vertical-align: top">
<td style="width: 0.5in"></td><td style="width: 0.25in"><font style="font-family: Symbol">&#183;</font></td><td>Fashion model and social media influencer management</td></tr></table>

<table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"><tr style="vertical-align: top">
<td style="width: 0.5in"></td><td style="width: 0.25in"><font style="font-family: Symbol">&#183;</font></td><td>Celebrity management</td></tr></table>

<table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"><tr style="vertical-align: top">
<td style="width: 0.5in"></td><td style="width: 0.25in"><font style="font-family: Symbol">&#183;</font></td><td>Licensing and branding associations</td></tr></table>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">During the third quarter of 2020, Wilhelmina ceased representation of
hair and make-up artists, to better focus on core fashion model and social media influencer talent. The Wilhelmina Studio division,
which offered services relating to content creation, production, casting, and influencer programming, was closed and ceased operations
during the fourth quarter of 2019.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"><i>Fashion Model and Social Media Influencer Management</i></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">Wilhelmina is focused on providing fashion modeling
talent and social media influencer services to clients such as advertising agencies, branded consumer goods companies, fashion
designers, Internet sites, retailers, department stores, product catalogs and magazine publications.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">The fashion model/talent/influencer management industry
can be divided into many subcategories, including advertising campaigns, catalog/e-commerce, runway, showroom and editorial work.&nbsp;Advertising
work involves modeling for advertisements featuring consumer products such as cosmetics, clothing and other items to be placed
in magazines and newspapers, on billboards and with other types of media.&nbsp;Catalog and e-commerce work involves modeling of
products to be sold through promotional catalogs and Internet commerce sites.&nbsp;Runway work involves modeling at fashion shows,
which primarily take place in Paris, Milan, London and New York City.&nbsp;Showroom work involves on-site modeling of products
at client showrooms and other events and production &#8220;fit&#8221; work whereby a model serves as the sizing model for apparel
items. Editorial work involves modeling for the cover and editorial sections of magazines and websites.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"></p>

<!-- Field: Page; Sequence: 4 -->
    <div style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-bottom: 6pt; border-bottom: Black 4pt solid"><table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse: collapse; width: 100%; font-size: 10pt"><tr style="vertical-align: top; text-align: left"><td style="width: 33%">&nbsp;</td><td style="width: 34%; text-align: center"><!-- Field: Sequence; Type: Arabic; Name: PageNo -->4<!-- Field: /Sequence --></td><td style="width: 33%; text-align: right">&nbsp;</td></tr></table></div>
    <div style="page-break-before: always; margin-top: 6pt; margin-bottom: 6pt"><p style="margin: 0pt">&nbsp;</p></div>
    <!-- Field: /Page -->

<p style="margin: 0; font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in">Clients pay for talent to appear in photo shoots
for Internet sites, magazine features, print advertising, direct mail marketing, and product catalogs, as well as to appear in
runway shows to present new designer collections, fit modeling, and on-location presentations and events.&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition,
talent may also appear in film and television commercials. Wilhelmina develops and diversifies its talent portfolio through a combination
of ongoing local, regional and international scouting and talent-search efforts to source new talent, as well as cooperating with
other agencies that represent talent.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">Within its fashion model management business, Wilhelmina
has two primary sources of service revenue:&nbsp;(i) commissions paid by models as a percentage of their gross earnings; and (ii)
service charges paid by clients in addition to booking fees, calculated as a percentage of the models&#8217; booking fees.&nbsp;&nbsp;Wilhelmina
believes that its commission rates and service charges are comparable to those of its principal competitors.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">Wilhelmina&#8217;s fashion model management operations
are organized into divisions called &#8220;boards,&#8221; each of which specializes by the type of models it represents.&nbsp;Wilhelmina&#8217;s
boards are generally described in the table below.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="width: 100%; border-collapse: collapse; font-size: 10pt">
<tr style="vertical-align: top">
    <td style="width: 25%; border-bottom: black 1pt solid"><font style="font-size: 10pt">Board Name</font></td>
    <td style="width: 33%; border-bottom: black 1pt solid"><font style="font-size: 10pt">Location</font></td>
    <td style="width: 42%; border-bottom: black 1pt solid"><font style="font-size: 10pt">Target Market</font></td></tr>
<tr style="vertical-align: top; background-color: rgb(204,238,255)">
    <td><font style="font-size: 10pt">Women</font></td>
    <td><font style="font-size: 10pt">NYC, LA, Miami, Chicago, London</font></td>
    <td><font style="font-size: 10pt">High-end female fashion models</font></td></tr>
<tr style="vertical-align: top; background-color: White">
    <td><font style="font-size: 10pt">Men</font></td>
    <td><font style="font-size: 10pt">NYC, LA, Miami, Chicago, London</font></td>
    <td><font style="font-size: 10pt">High-end male fashion models</font></td></tr>
<tr style="vertical-align: top; background-color: rgb(204,238,255)">
    <td><font style="font-size: 10pt">Direct</font></td>
    <td><font style="font-size: 10pt">NYC, LA, Miami, Chicago, London</font></td>
    <td><font style="font-size: 10pt">Established/commercial male/female fashion models</font></td></tr>
<tr style="vertical-align: top; background-color: White">
    <td><font style="font-size: 10pt">Curve</font></td>
    <td><font style="font-size: 10pt">NYC, LA, Miami, London</font></td>
    <td><font style="font-size: 10pt">Full-figured female fashion models</font></td></tr>
<tr style="vertical-align: top; background-color: rgb(204,238,255)">
    <td><font style="font-size: 10pt">Showroom</font></td>
    <td><font style="font-size: 10pt">NYC, Miami</font></td>
    <td><font style="font-size: 10pt">Live modeling and designer fit clothing modeling</font></td></tr>
<tr style="vertical-align: top; background-color: White">
    <td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid"><font style="font-size: 10pt">Fitness</font></td>
    <td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid"><font style="font-size: 10pt">NYC, LA</font></td>
    <td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid"><font style="font-size: 10pt">Athletic models</font></td></tr>
</table>
<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: -0.5in; margin: 0 0 0 0.5in">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0; text-indent: 0.5in">Each
major board is headed by a director who manages the agents assigned to the board.&nbsp;The agents of each board act both as bookers
(including promoting models, negotiating fees and contracting work) and as talent scouts/managers (including providing models with
career and development guidance and helping them better market themselves).&nbsp;Although agents individually develop professional
relationships with models, models are represented by a board collectively and not by a specific agent.&nbsp;Wilhelmina&#8217;s
organization into boards enables Wilhelmina to provide clients with services tailored to their particular needs, to allow models
to benefit from agents&#8217; specialized experience in their particular markets, and to limit Wilhelmina&#8217;s dependency on
any specialty market or agent.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">Most senior agents are employed pursuant to employment
agreements that include noncompetition provisions such as a prohibition from working with Wilhelmina&#8217;s models and clients
for a certain period of time after the end of the agent&#8217;s employment with Wilhelmina. Wilhelmina typically signs its models
to three-year exclusive contracts, which it actively enforces.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">The Aperture division operates in New York and Los
Angeles, and offers models, social media influencers, and actors representation for commercials, film, and television.&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">Wilhelmina London Limited (&#8220;London&#8221;),
a wholly owned subsidiary of Wilhelmina International, Inc., was acquired in January 2015. The London subsidiary establishes a
footprint for the Company in Western Europe, provides a base of operations to service the Company&#8217;s European clients, and
serves as a new talent development office for European models and artists.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"><i>Celebrity Management</i></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">Wilhelmina&#8217;s Celebrity division seeks to secure
endorsement and spokesperson work for celebrities from the worlds of sports, music and entertainment.&nbsp;The Celebrity division
has two primary sources of revenue:&nbsp;(i) commissions paid by talent as a percentage of their gross earnings; and (ii) royalties
or a service charge paid by clients. Wilhelmina&#8217;s Celebrity division management works with emerging artists and established
celebrity names to match them with leading fashion brands and companies.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"><i>&nbsp;</i></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"><i>Licensing &amp; Branding Associations</i></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">Wilhelmina Licensing, LLC is a wholly-owned subsidiary
that collects third-party licensing fees in connection with the licensing of the &#8220;Wilhelmina&#8221; name.&nbsp;Third-party
licensees include several leading fashion model agencies in local markets in the U.S. and internationally. The film and television
business consists of occasional television syndication royalties and production series contracts. Also, from time to time, the
Company conducts model search contests and other events in an effort to expand the Wilhelmina brand and recruit talent.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0"><b>&nbsp;</b></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0"></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"><b></b></p>

<!-- Field: Page; Sequence: 5 -->
    <div style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-bottom: 6pt; border-bottom: Black 4pt solid"><table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse: collapse; width: 100%; font-size: 10pt"><tr style="vertical-align: top; text-align: left"><td style="width: 33%">&nbsp;</td><td style="width: 34%; text-align: center"><!-- Field: Sequence; Type: Arabic; Name: PageNo -->5<!-- Field: /Sequence --></td><td style="width: 33%; text-align: right">&nbsp;</td></tr></table></div>
    <div style="page-break-before: always; margin-top: 6pt; margin-bottom: 6pt"><p style="margin: 0pt">&nbsp;</p></div>
    <!-- Field: /Page -->

<p style="margin: 0; font-size: 10pt"><b>Competition</b></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">The fashion model/talent management business is
highly competitive.&nbsp;New York City, Los Angeles, and Miami, as well as London, Paris, and Milan, are considered the most important
markets for the fashion talent management industry.&nbsp;&nbsp;Most of the leading international firms are headquartered in New
York City.&nbsp;Wilhelmina&#8217;s principal competitors include other large fashion model management businesses in the U.S., including
IMG Models, Elite Model Management, Ford Models, Inc., DNA Model Management, NEXT Model Management, The Lions Model Management,
The Society Management, Women 360 Management, and New York Model Management. However, Wilhelmina is the only publicly-owned fashion
talent management company in the world.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">Competition also includes foreign agencies and smaller
U.S. agencies in local markets that recruit local talent and cater to local market needs.&nbsp;&nbsp;Several of the larger fashion
talent firms operate offices in multiple cities and countries or have chosen to partner with local or foreign agencies.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">The Company believes that its sources of revenue,
mainly generated from commissions and service charges, are comparable to those of its principal competitors.&nbsp;&nbsp;Therefore,
for the Company to obtain a competitive advantage, it must develop and maintain a deep pool of talent and deliver high quality
service to its clients.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company believes that through its scouting efforts, name recognition, and licensing network,
it is able to recruit a deeper pool of talent relative to its competitors.&nbsp;These recruitment tools, coupled with the broad
range of fashion boards available to the Company&#8217;s talent, enable the Company to develop talent and generate a broader range
of revenues relative to its principal competitors.&nbsp;While a broad range of talent and boards provides a level of stability
to the business, certain talent may be more inclined to work with a boutique agency that may appear to tailor more specifically
to their needs.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">For more than 50 years, Wilhelmina and its predecessors
have created long-standing client relationships and business activities related to the fashion model management business that provide
exposure to diverse markets and demographics.&nbsp;The Company has also developed a professional workforce with years of talent
management experience.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"><b>&nbsp;</b></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"><b></b></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"><b>Clients and Customers</b></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0; text-indent: 0.5in">As
of December 31, 2020, Wilhelmina represented a roster of approximately 1,500 active models and talent.&nbsp;Wilhelmina&#8217;s
active models include Karol&#237;na Kurkov&#225;, Ana Maria Figuerova, Asya Rosh, Bianca Balti, Francisco Henriques, Carla
Piera, Alva Clair, Bojana Krsmanovic, Cyrielle Lalande, Mitchell Slaggert, Anne de Paula, Ottawa Efoe, Rainer Andreesen, Erik Van
Gils, Kate King, Parker Gregory, Malik Lindo, Malcolm Jackson, Milena Feuerer, Oumar Diouf, Marianna Dantec, Haejin Lee, Hilda
Halilovic, Moon Young, Kailand Morris, Riley Harper, Isabela Grutman, Sabey Dantsira, Lauren Auerbach, Davidson Obennebo, Mikkel
Jensen, Sasha Melnychuk, Armando Cabral, Lola Hedrickx, Vanessa Cruz, Tommy Hackett, Serena Marquez, Nadia Lee Cohen, Sofia Tesmenitskaya,
Nayara Oliviera, Fernando Lindez, Dachuan Jin, Thais Borges, Gracie Phillips, Ludwig Wilsdorff, Claudio Montiero, and Nathan Owens.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">Wilhelmina serves approximately 2,400 external clients.&nbsp;Wilhelmina&#8217;s
customer base is highly diversified, with no one customer accounting for more than 3% of overall gross revenues.&nbsp;The top 100
clients of Wilhelmina together accounted for approximately 46% of overall gross revenues during 2020.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"><b></b></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"><b>Governmental Regulations</b></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">Certain jurisdictions in which Wilhelmina operates,
such as California and Florida, require that companies maintain a Talent Agency License in order to engage in the &#8220;talent
agency&#8221; business.&nbsp;The talent agency business is generally considered the business of procuring engagements or any employment
or placement of a talent, where the talent performs in his or her artistic capacity.&nbsp;&nbsp;Where required, the Wilhelmina
subsidiaries operating in these jurisdictions maintain Talent Agency Licenses issued by those jurisdictions.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0"></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"><b>Trends and Opportunities</b></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">The Company expects that the combination of Wilhelmina&#8217;s
main operating base in New York City, the industry&#8217;s capital, with the depth and breadth of its talent pool, client roster
and its diversification across various talent management segments, together with its name recognition and geographical reach, should
make Wilhelmina&#8217;s operations more resilient to industry changes and economic swings than those of many of the smaller firms
operating in the industry.&nbsp;Similarly, in the segments where Wilhelmina competes with other leading full service agencies,
Wilhelmina believes it competed successfully in 2020.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">With total advertising expenditures on major media
(television, Internet, outdoor, cinema, magazines, and newspapers) of approximately $220 billion in 2020, North America is the
world&#8217;s largest advertising market.&nbsp;&nbsp;For the fashion talent management industry, including Wilhelmina, advertising
expenditures on television, Internet, magazines, and outdoor are of particular relevance.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"><b></b></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"></p>

<!-- Field: Page; Sequence: 6 -->
    <div style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-bottom: 6pt; border-bottom: Black 4pt solid"><table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse: collapse; width: 100%; font-size: 10pt"><tr style="vertical-align: top; text-align: left"><td style="width: 33%">&nbsp;</td><td style="width: 34%; text-align: center"><!-- Field: Sequence; Type: Arabic; Name: PageNo -->6<!-- Field: /Sequence --></td><td style="width: 33%; text-align: right">&nbsp;</td></tr></table></div>
    <div style="page-break-before: always; margin-top: 6pt; margin-bottom: 6pt"><p style="margin: 0pt">&nbsp;</p></div>
    <!-- Field: /Page -->

<p style="margin: 0; font-size: 10pt"><b>Strategy</b></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">Management&#8217;s strategy is to increase value to shareholders through
the following initiatives:</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"><tr style="vertical-align: top">
<td style="width: 0.5in"></td><td style="width: 0.25in">&#8226;</td><td>increase Wilhelmina&#8217;s brand awareness among advertisers and potential talent;</td></tr></table>

<table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"><tr style="vertical-align: top">
<td style="width: 0.5in"></td><td style="width: 0.25in">&#8226;</td><td>expand the women&#8217;s high end fashion board;</td></tr></table>

<table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"><tr style="vertical-align: top">
<td style="width: 0.5in"></td><td style="width: 0.25in">&#8226;</td><td>expand the Aperture division&#8217;s representation in commercials, film, and television;</td></tr></table>

<table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"><tr style="vertical-align: top">
<td style="width: 0.5in"></td><td style="width: 0.25in">&#8226;</td><td>expand celebrity and social media influencer representation;</td></tr></table>

<table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"><tr style="vertical-align: top">
<td style="width: 0.5in"></td><td style="width: 0.25in">&#8226;</td><td>expand the Wilhelmina network through strategic geographic market development; and</td></tr></table>

<table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"><tr style="vertical-align: top">
<td style="width: 0.5in"></td><td style="width: 0.25in">&#8226;</td><td>promote model search contests and events and partner on media projects (television, film, books, etc.).</td></tr></table>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">The Company makes use of digital technology to effectively
connect with clients and talent, utilizing video conferencing and other digital tools to best position our team to identify opportunities
to grow the careers of the talent we represent and expand our business. The Company has made significant investments in technology,
infrastructure, and personnel, to support our clients and talent.&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0"></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"><b>EMPLOYEES</b></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">As of December 31, 2020, the Company had 70 employees,
42 of whom were located in New York City, five of whom were located at Wilhelmina&#8217;s Miami office, 10 of whom were located
at Wilhelmina&#8217;s Los Angeles office, 11 of whom were located at Wilhelmina&#8217;s London office and two of whom were located
at the corporate headquarters in Dallas.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"><b>TRADEMARKS AND LICENSING</b></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">The &#8220;Wilhelmina&#8221; brand is essential
to the success and competitive position of the Company.&nbsp;The &#8220;Wilhelmina&#8221; trademark is vital to the licensing business
because licensees pay for the right to use the trademark.&nbsp;The Company has invested significant resources in the &#8220;Wilhelmina&#8221;
brands in order to obtain the public recognition that these brands currently enjoy.&nbsp;Wilhelmina&nbsp;relies upon domestic and
international trademark laws, license agreements and nondisclosure agreements to protect the &#8220;Wilhelmina&#8221; brand name
used in its business.&nbsp;Trademarks registered in the U.S. have a duration of ten years and are generally subject to an indefinite
number of renewals for a like period on continued use and appropriate application.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"></p>

<table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"><tr style="vertical-align: top">
<td style="width: 0"></td><td style="width: 1in"><b><a name="a_009"></a>ITEM 1A.</b></td><td><i>RISK FACTORS</i></td></tr></table>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0 0 8pt; color: #252525">Not applicable to smaller
reporting company.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"><tr style="vertical-align: top">
<td style="width: 0"></td><td style="width: 1in"><b><a name="a_010"></a>ITEM 1B.</b></td><td><i>UNRESOLVED STAFF COMMENTS</i></td></tr></table>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">None.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: -1in; margin: 0 0 0 1in"><b>&nbsp;</b></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: -1in; margin: 0 0 0 1in"><b></b></p>

<table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"><tr style="vertical-align: top">
<td style="width: 0"></td><td style="width: 1in"><b><a name="a_011"></a>ITEM 2.</b></td><td><i>PROPERTIES</i></td></tr></table>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">The Company&#8217;s corporate headquarters are currently
located at 200 Crescent Court, Suite 1400, Dallas, Texas 75201, which are also the offices of Newcastle Capital Management, L.P.
(&#8220;NCM&#8221;).&nbsp;&nbsp;NCM is the general partner of Newcastle Partners L.P. (&#8220;Newcastle&#8221;), the Company&#8217;s
largest shareholder.&nbsp;The Company occupies a portion of NCM&#8217;s space on a month-to-month basis at $2,500 per month, pursuant
to a services agreement entered into between the parties in 2006.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"></p>

<!-- Field: Page; Sequence: 7 -->
    <div style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-bottom: 6pt; border-bottom: Black 4pt solid"><table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse: collapse; width: 100%; font-size: 10pt"><tr style="vertical-align: top; text-align: left"><td style="width: 33%">&nbsp;</td><td style="width: 34%; text-align: center"><!-- Field: Sequence; Type: Arabic; Name: PageNo -->7<!-- Field: /Sequence --></td><td style="width: 33%; text-align: right">&nbsp;</td></tr></table></div>
    <div style="page-break-before: always; margin-top: 6pt; margin-bottom: 6pt"><p style="margin: 0pt">&nbsp;</p></div>

<p style="margin: 0; font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in"></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">The following table summarizes information with
respect to the material facilities of the Company for leased office space and model apartments:</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

    <td style="text-align: center"><font style="font-size: 10pt">2,000</font></td>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">The Company&#8217;s lease on its former New York City offices expired
in February 2021. Due to all of the New York staff working remotely during the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, Wilhelmina elected not
to renew the lease and vacated the premises. The Company presently expects that all employees based in New York will continue to
work remotely until it is deemed safe to return to an office environment. At that time, Wilhelmina expects to lease a new office
space for its New York City operational headquarters. The Company believes there is sufficient office space available at favorable
leasing terms to replace its former office space and to satisfy any need for future expansion.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"><tr style="vertical-align: top">
<td style="width: 0"></td><td style="width: 1in"><b><a name="a_012"></a>ITEM 3.</b></td><td><i>LEGAL PROCEEDINGS</i></td></tr></table>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: justify; font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">On October 24, 2013, a putative class action
lawsuit was brought against the Company by former Wilhelmina model Alex Shanklin and others, including Louisa Raske, Carina Vretman,
Grecia Palomares and Michelle Griffin Trotter (the &#8220;Shanklin Litigation&#8221;), in New York State Supreme Court (New York
County)&nbsp;by the same lead&nbsp;counsel who represented plaintiffs in a prior, now-dismissed action brought by Louisa Raske
(the &#8220;Raske Litigation&#8221;).&nbsp; The claims in the Shanklin Litigation initially included breach of contract and unjust
enrichment allegations arising out of matters similar to the Raske Litigation, such as the handling and reporting of funds on behalf&nbsp;of
models and the use of model images.&nbsp; Other parties&nbsp;named as defendants in the Shanklin Litigation include other model
management companies, advertising firms, and certain advertisers.&nbsp; On January 6, 2014, the Company moved to dismiss the Amended
Complaint in the Shanklin Litigation for failure to state a claim upon which relief can be granted and other grounds, and other
defendants also filed motions to dismiss.&nbsp; On August 11, 2014, the court denied the motion to dismiss as to Wilhelmina and
other of the model management defendants.&nbsp; Separately, on March 3, 2014, the judge assigned to the Shanklin Litigation wrote
the Office of the New York Attorney General bringing the case to&nbsp;its attention, generally describing the claims asserted therein
against the model management defendants, and stating that the case &#8220;may involve matters in the public interest.&#8221;&nbsp;The
judge&#8217;s letter also enclosed a copy of his decision in the Raske Litigation, which dismissed that case.&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0 0 0pt; font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in">Plaintiffs retained substitute counsel, who filed a Second and then Third Amended Complaint.&nbsp;Plaintiffs&#8217; Third Amended
Complaint asserts causes of action for alleged breaches of the plaintiffs' management contracts with the defendants, conversion,
breach of the duty of good faith and fair dealing, and unjust enrichment.&nbsp; The Third Amended Complaint also alleges that the
plaintiff models were at all relevant times employees, and not independent contractors, of the model management defendants, and
that defendants violated the New York Labor Law in several respects, including, among other things, by allegedly failing to pay
the models the minimum wages and overtime pay required thereunder, not maintaining accurate payroll records, and not providing
plaintiffs with full explanations of how their wages and deductions therefrom were computed.&nbsp; The Third Amended Complaint
seeks certification of the action as a class action, damages in an amount to be determined at trial, plus interest, costs, attorneys&#8217;
fees, and such other relief as the court deems proper.&nbsp; On October 6, 2015, Wilhelmina filed a motion to dismiss as to most
of the plaintiffs&#8217; claims.&nbsp; The Court entered a decision granting in part and denying in part Wilhelmina&#8217;s motion
to dismiss on May 26, 2017.&nbsp; The Court (i) dismissed three of the five New York Labor Law causes of action, along with the
conversion, breach of the duty of good faith and fair dealing and unjust enrichment causes of action, in their entirety, and (ii)
permitted only the breach of contract causes of action, and some plaintiffs&#8217; remaining two New York Labor Law causes of action
to continue, within a limited time frame.&nbsp; The plaintiffs&nbsp;and Wilhelmina&nbsp;each appealed, and the decision was affirmed
on May 24, 2018.&nbsp;On August 16, 2017,&nbsp;Wilhelmina timely filed its Answer to the Third Amended Complaint.</p>

<p style="margin: 0 0 0pt; font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0; text-align: justify; font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 0.5in">On June 6, 2016, another putative class action lawsuit was brought against the Company by former Wilhelmina model Shawn Pressley
and others, including Roberta Little (the &#8220;Pressley Litigation&#8221;), in New York State Supreme Court (New York County)
by the same counsel representing the plaintiffs in the Shanklin Litigation, and asserting identical, although more recent, claims
as those in the Shanklin Litigation.&nbsp; The Amended Complaint, asserting essentially the same types of claims as in the Shanklin
action, was filed on August 16, 2017.&nbsp; Wilhelmina filed a motion to dismiss the Amended Complaint on September 29, 2017, which
was granted in part and denied in part on May 10, 2018. &nbsp;Some New York Labor Law and contract claims remain in the case.&nbsp;
Pressley has withdrawn from the case, leaving Roberta Little as the sole remaining named plaintiff in the Pressley Litigation.
&nbsp;On July 12, 2019, the Company filed its Answer and Counterclaim against Little.</p>

<p style="margin: 0; text-align: justify; font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 0.5in">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"></p>

<!-- Field: Page; Sequence: 8 -->
    <div style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-bottom: 6pt; border-bottom: Black 4pt solid"><table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse: collapse; width: 100%; font-size: 10pt"><tr style="vertical-align: top; text-align: left"><td style="width: 33%">&nbsp;</td><td style="width: 34%; text-align: center"><!-- Field: Sequence; Type: Arabic; Name: PageNo -->8<!-- Field: /Sequence --></td><td style="width: 33%; text-align: right">&nbsp;</td></tr></table></div>
    <div style="page-break-before: always; margin-top: 6pt; margin-bottom: 6pt"><p style="margin: 0pt">&nbsp;</p></div>
    <!-- Field: /Page -->

<p style="margin: 0 0 0pt; font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in">On May 1, 2019, the Plaintiffs in the Shanklin Litigation (except Raske) and the Pressley Litigation filed motions for class certification
on their contract claims and the remaining New York Labor Law Claims. On July 12, 2019, Wilhelmina filed its opposition to the
motions for class certification and filed a cross-motion for summary judgment against Shanklin, Vretman, Palomares, Trotter and
Little, and a motion for summary judgment against Raske.&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0 0 0pt; font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0 0 0pt">By Order Dated May 8, 2020 (the &#8220;Class
Certification Order&#8221;), the Court denied class certification in the Pressley case, denied class certification with respect
to the breach of contract and alleged unpaid usage claims, granted class certification as to the New York Labor Law causes of action
asserted by Vretman, Palomares and Trotter, and declined to rule on Wilhelmina&#8217;s motions for summary judgment, denying them
without prejudice to be re-filed at a later date. On June 12, 2020, the Plaintiffs in both the Shanklin and Pressley actions filed
Notices of Appeal to the Appellate Division, First Department, from those portions of the Class Certification Order on which Wilhelmina
prevailed. On June 22, 2020, Wilhelmina filed Notices of Cross-Appeal from those portions of the Class Certification order that
granted class Certification and denied summary judgment. The Court has directed the parties to non-binding mediation and that process
is underway.</p>

<p style="margin: 0 0 0pt; font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0 0 0pt">The Company believes the claims asserted in
the Shanklin Litigation and Pressley Litigation are without merit and intends to continue to vigorously defend the actions.</p>

<p style="margin: 0 0 0pt; font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0 0 0pt">In addition to the legal proceedings disclosed
herein, the Company is also engaged in various legal proceedings that are routine in nature and incidental to its business. None
of these routine proceedings, either individually or in the aggregate, are believed likely, in the Company's opinion, to have a
material adverse effect on its consolidated financial position or its results of operations.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0"></p>

<table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"><tr style="vertical-align: top">
<td style="width: 0"></td><td style="width: 1in"><a name="a_013"></a><b>ITEM 4.</b></td><td><i>MINE SAFETY DISCLOSURES</i></td></tr></table>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0">Not applicable.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

    <div style="page-break-before: always; margin-top: 6pt; margin-bottom: 6pt"><p style="margin: 0pt">&nbsp;</p></div>
    <!-- Field: /Page -->

<p style="margin: 0; font-size: 10pt"></p>

<p style="text-align: center; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"><b><a name="a_014"></a>PART II</b></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: center; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"><tr style="vertical-align: top">
<td style="width: 0"></td><td style="width: 1in"><b><a name="a_015"></a>ITEM 5.</b></td><td><i>MARKET FOR REGISTRANT&#8217;S COMMON EQUITY, RELATED STOCKHOLDER MATTERS AND ISSUER PURCHASES OF EQUITY SECURITIES</i></td></tr></table>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"><b>Market Information </b></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"><b>&nbsp;</b></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">The Company&#8217;s $0.01 par value common stock
has traded on the Nasdaq Capital Market under the symbol &#8220;WHLM&#8221; since September 2014. Previously, the common stock
was quoted in the over-the-counter market on the OTC Bulletin Board.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">The following table shows the high and low sales
prices of the common stock for each calendar quarter of 2019 and 2020.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"><b>&nbsp;</b></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"><b></b></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"><b>Issuer Repurchases</b></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0; text-indent: 0.5in">During 2012, the Board of Directors authorized a
stock repurchase program whereby the Company could repurchase up to 500,000 shares of its outstanding common stock. During 2013,
the Board of Directors renewed and extended the Company&#8217;s share repurchase authority to enable it to repurchase up to an
aggregate of 1,000,000 shares of common stock. In 2016, the Board of Directors increased by an additional 500,000 shares the number
of shares of the Company&#8217;s common stock which may be repurchased under its stock repurchase program to an aggregate of 1,500,000
shares. The shares may be repurchased from time to time in the open market or through privately negotiated transactions at prices
the Company deems appropriate. The program does not obligate the Company to acquire any particular amount of common stock and may
be modified or suspended at any time at the Company&#8217;s discretion. The Company did not make any purchases pursuant to the
stock repurchase program during the quarter ended December 31, 2020.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"></p>

<!-- Field: Page; Sequence: 10 -->
    <div style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-bottom: 6pt; border-bottom: Black 4pt solid"><table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse: collapse; width: 100%; font-size: 10pt"><tr style="vertical-align: top; text-align: left"><td style="width: 33%">&nbsp;</td><td style="width: 34%; text-align: center"><!-- Field: Sequence; Type: Arabic; Name: PageNo -->10<!-- Field: /Sequence --></td><td style="width: 33%; text-align: right">&nbsp;</td></tr></table></div>

    <!-- Field: /Page -->

<p style="margin: 0; font-size: 10pt"><b>Shareholders</b></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">As of March 16, 2021 there were 5,157,344 shares of the Company&#8217;s
common stock outstanding held by 437 holders of record.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"><b>Dividend Policy</b></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">The Company has not declared or paid any cash dividends
on its common stock during the past two completed fiscal years.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Board of Directors of the Company expects to continue
this policy for the foreseeable future in order to retain cash for the continued expansion of the Company&#8217;s business. The
Company&#8217;s credit agreement with Amegy Bank contains a covenant which could limit its ability to pay dividends on the common
stock.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"></p>

<table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"><tr style="vertical-align: top">
<td style="width: 0"></td><td style="width: 1in"><b><a name="a_016"></a>ITEM 6.</b></td><td><i>SELECTED FINANCIAL DATA</i></td></tr></table>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">Not applicable to smaller reporting company.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0"></p>

<table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="100%" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"><tr style="vertical-align: top">
<td style="width: 0"></td><td style="width: 1in"><b><a name="a_017"></a>ITEM 7.</b></td><td><i>MANAGEMENT&#8217;S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</i></td></tr></table>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">The following is a discussion of the Company&#8217;s
financial condition and results of operations comparing the calendar years ended December 31, 2020 and 2019.&nbsp;This section
should be read in conjunction with the Company&#8217;s Consolidated Financial Statements and the Notes thereto that are incorporated
herein by reference and the other financial information included herein and the notes thereto.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"><b>&nbsp;</b></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"><b></b></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"><b>OVERVIEW</b></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">The Company&#8217;s primary business is fashion
model management and complementary business activities. The business of talent management firms, such as Wilhelmina, depends heavily
on the state of the advertising industry, as demand for talent is driven by digital, mobile, print and television advertising campaigns
for consumer goods, e-commerce, and retail clients. Wilhelmina believes it has strong brand recognition, which enables it to attract
and retain top agents and talent to service a broad universe of clients. In order to take advantage of these opportunities and
support its continued growth, the Company will need to continue to successfully allocate resources and staffing in a way that enhances
its ability to respond to new opportunities. The Company continues to focus on tightly managing costs, recruiting top agents, and
scouting and developing talent.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">Although Wilhelmina has a large and diverse client
base, it is not immune to global economic conditions, such as the impact from the COVID-19 pandemic. The Company closely monitors
economic conditions, client spending, and other industry factors and continually evaluates opportunities to increase the market
share of its existing boards and further expand its geographic reach.&nbsp;There can be no assurance as to the effects on Wilhelmina
of future economic circumstances, technological developments, client spending patterns, client creditworthiness and other developments
and whether, or to what extent, Wilhelmina&#8217;s efforts to respond to them will be effective.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0"></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"><b>COVID-19 PANDEMIC</b></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0; background-color: white">On March 11, 2020, the
World Health Organization declared the outbreak of novel coronavirus (COVID-19) as a pandemic, which spread rapidly throughout
the United States and the world. As the global impact of COVID-19 continues, Wilhelmina&#8217;s first priority has been to protect
the health and safety of its employees and talent. To help mitigate the spread of the virus and in response to health advisories
and governmental actions and regulations, the Company has modified its business practices and has implemented health and safety
measures that are designed to protect employees and represented talent.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0; background-color: white">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0; background-color: white">The Company&#8217;s revenues
are heavily dependent on the level of economic activity in the United States and the United Kingdom, particularly in the fashion,
advertising and publishing industries, all of which have been negatively impacted by the pandemic and may not recover as quickly
as other sectors of the economy. There have been mandates from federal, state, and local authorities requiring forced closures
of non-essential businesses. As a result, beginning in March 2020, the Company saw a significant reduction in customer bookings,
resulting in a negative impact to revenue and earnings. During the second half of 2020, bookings increased from the preceding months,
but remained significantly below pre-pandemic levels.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0; background-color: white">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0; background-color: white"></p>

<!-- Field: Page; Sequence: 11 -->
    <div style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-bottom: 6pt; border-bottom: Black 4pt solid"><table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse: collapse; width: 100%; font-size: 10pt"><tr style="vertical-align: top; text-align: left"><td style="width: 33%">&nbsp;</td><td style="width: 34%; text-align: center"><!-- Field: Sequence; Type: Arabic; Name: PageNo -->11<!-- Field: /Sequence --></td><td style="width: 33%; text-align: right">&nbsp;</td></tr></table></div>
    <div style="page-break-before: always; margin-top: 6pt; margin-bottom: 6pt"><p style="margin: 0pt">&nbsp;</p></div>
    <!-- Field: /Page -->

<p style="margin: 0; font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; background-color: white">In addition to reduced
revenue, business operations have been adversely affected by reductions in productivity, limitations on the ability of customers
to make timely payments, disruptions in talents&#8217; ability to travel to needed locations, and supply chain disruptions impeding
clothing or footwear wardrobe from reaching destinations for photoshoots and other bookings. Many of the Company&#8217;s customers
are large retail and fashion companies, some of which have had to close stores in the United States and internationally due to
the spread of COVID-19. Some of these customers have filed for bankruptcy in 2020 and others may be unable to pay amounts already
owed to the Company, resulting in increased current and future bad debt expense. These customers also may not emerge from the pandemic
with the financial ability, or need, to purchase Wilhelmina&#8217;s services to the extent that they did in previous years. Some
model talent have been quarantined with family far from the major cities where Wilhelmina&#8217;s offices are located, and also
away from where most modeling jobs take place. Many U.S. and international airlines have decreased their flight schedules which,
as economic activities resumes and clients increase booking requests, may make it difficult for talent to be available when and
where they are needed. The B.1.1.7 variant of the COVID-19 virus, which is believed to spread easily and quickly, has particularly
impacted the United Kingdom in recent months, resulting in renewed strict lockdowns that have impacted Wilhelmina&#8217;s London
operations and are continuing into 2021. While these disruptions are currently expected to be temporary, there continues to be
uncertainty around the duration.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0; background-color: white">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0; background-color: white">Postponed and cancelled
bookings related to the pandemic contributed significantly to reduced revenues and increased operating losses during 2020. Although
some clients increased activity and bookings during the second half of 2020, rising COVID-19 infection rates in cities where Wilhelmina
operates could lead to a slower economic recovery in those markets, and possible additional business closings or local mandates
that could slow the recovery in operations there. Since Wilhelmina extends customary payment terms to its clients, even as bookings
resume, there is likely to be a lag before significant cash collections return. In the meantime, the Company continues to have
significant employee, office rent, and other expenses.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0; background-color: white">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0; background-color: white">Reduced outstanding accounts
receivable available as collateral under the Company&#8217;s credit agreement with Amegy Bank has limited its access to additional
financing. Net losses in recent periods have also impacted compliance with the financial covenants under the Amegy Bank credit
agreement, further impeding the Company&#8217;s ability to obtain additional financing. Since the pandemic began, many stock markets,
including Nasdaq Capital Market where Wilhelmina&#8217;s common stock is listed, have been volatile. A further decline in the Company&#8217;s
stock price would reduce its market capitalization and could require additional goodwill or intangible asset impairment writedowns.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0; background-color: white">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0; background-color: white">The Company has taken the
following actions to address the impact of COVID-19 and the current recessionary environment, in order to efficiently manage the
business and maintain adequate liquidity and maximum flexibility:</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0; background-color: white">&nbsp;</p>

<table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="width: 100%; background-color: white; font-size: 10pt">
<tr style="vertical-align: top">
    <td style="width: 48px">&nbsp;</td>
    <td style="width: 24px"><font style="font-size: 10pt">-</font></td>
    <td style="text-align: justify"><font style="font-size: 10pt">In April 2020, obtained approximately $2.0 million in loans under the Paycheck Protection Program (the &#8220;PPP&#8221;) of the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (the &#8220;CARES Act&#8221;) administered by the U.S. Small Business Administration (&#8220;SBA&#8221;).</font></td></tr>
</table>
<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"></p>

<table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="width: 100%; background-color: white; font-size: 10pt">
<tr style="vertical-align: top">
    <td style="width: 48px">&nbsp;</td>
    <td style="width: 24px"><font style="font-size: 10pt">-</font></td>
    <td style="text-align: justify"><font style="font-size: 10pt">Eliminated discretionary travel and entertainment expenses.</font></td></tr>
</table>
<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"></p>

<table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="width: 100%; background-color: white; font-size: 10pt">
<tr style="vertical-align: top">
    <td style="width: 48px">&nbsp;</td>
    <td style="width: 24px"><font style="font-size: 10pt">-</font></td>
    <td style="text-align: justify"><font style="font-size: 10pt">Suspended share repurchases.&nbsp;&nbsp;The terms of the Company&#8217;s PPP loans restrict share repurchases until 12 months have passed after full repayment. </font></td></tr>
</table>
<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"></p>

<table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="width: 100%; background-color: white; font-size: 10pt">
<tr style="vertical-align: top">
    <td style="width: 48px">&nbsp;</td>
    <td style="width: 24px"><font style="font-size: 10pt">-</font></td>
    <td style="text-align: justify"><font style="font-size: 10pt">Did not renew the leases on three New York City model apartments when the terms ended in June and August, 2020.</font></td></tr>
<tr style="vertical-align: top">
    <td><font style="font-size: 10pt">&nbsp;</font></td>
    <td><font style="font-size: 10pt">-</font></td>
    <td style="text-align: justify"><font style="font-size: 10pt">Did not renew the lease on the Company&#8217;s New York City office, and required all New York based staff to work remotely.</font></td></tr>
</table>
<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"></p>

<table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="width: 100%; background-color: white; font-size: 10pt">
<tr style="vertical-align: top">
    <td style="width: 48px">&nbsp;</td>
    <td style="width: 24px"><font style="font-size: 10pt">-</font></td>
    <td style="text-align: justify"><font style="font-size: 10pt">Suspended efforts to fill two highly compensated executive
roles following the resignation of the Company&#8217;s Chief Executive Officer and Vice President in early 2020.</font></td></tr>
</table>
<table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="width: 100%; background-color: white; font-size: 10pt">
<tr style="vertical-align: top">
    <td style="width: 48px">&nbsp;</td>
    <td style="width: 24px"><font style="font-size: 10pt">-</font></td>
    <td style="text-align: justify"><font style="font-size: 10pt">Negotiated discounts with various vendors and service providers.</font></td></tr>
</table>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"></p>

<table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="width: 100%; background-color: white; font-size: 10pt">
<tr style="vertical-align: top">
    <td style="width: 48px">&nbsp;</td>
    <td style="width: 24px"><font style="font-size: 10pt">-</font></td>
    <td style="text-align: justify"><font style="font-size: 10pt">Effective July 1, 2020, implemented
layoffs of approximately 36% of its staff, including employees at each of the Company&#8217;s five offices, and effected temporary
salary reductions for the remaining staff.</font></td></tr>
</table>

<p style="margin: 0 0 0 0.5in; font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; background-color: white"></p>

<p style="margin: 0 0 0 0.5in; font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; background-color: white"></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0; background-color: white">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0; background-color: white">If the quarantines and
limitations on non-essential work are re-implemented, or persist for an extended period, the Company may need to implement additional
cost savings measures.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0 13.5pt 0 0">The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2021, which includes
The COVID-related Tax Relief Act of 2020 and the Taxpayer Certainty and Disaster Tax Relief Act of 2020, was passed and signed
into law the last week of 2020.&nbsp; The many provisions of the legislation include items such as expenses associated with forgiven
PPP loans, business meals deductions, individual tax rebates and unemployment benefits.&nbsp; The Company is currently evaluating
the impact of this new legislation.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0"></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"><b>BREXIT</b></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0; text-indent: 0.5in">On January 31, 2020, the United Kingdom (&#8220;UK&#8221;)
withdrew from the European Union (&#8220;EU&#8221;). Effective January 1, 2021, new visa requirements and other restrictions limit
the freedom of movement for British workers to travel to the EU for work, which may impact the ability of the Company&#8217;s London
office to book modeling photoshoots that take place in the European Union. It may also be more difficult, in the future, for talent
represented by Wilhelmina London, but based in the EU, to travel to London and other parts of the UK for photoshoots and campaign
work. New immigration sponsorship or visa requirements could discourage fashion brands, and other clients, from booking as frequently
in London, which has historically been an international fashion and modeling hub, and could impact the revenue of the Company&#8217;s
London operations.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0"></p>

<!-- Field: Page; Sequence: 12 -->
    <div style="margin-top: 6pt; margin-bottom: 6pt; border-bottom: Black 4pt solid"><table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse: collapse; width: 100%; font-size: 10pt"><tr style="vertical-align: top; text-align: left"><td style="width: 33%">&nbsp;</td><td style="width: 34%; text-align: center"><!-- Field: Sequence; Type: Arabic; Name: PageNo -->12<!-- Field: /Sequence --></td><td style="width: 33%; text-align: right">&nbsp;</td></tr></table></div>
    <div style="page-break-before: always; margin-top: 6pt; margin-bottom: 6pt"><p style="margin: 0pt">&nbsp;</p></div>
    <!-- Field: /Page -->

<p style="margin: 0; font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify"></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"><b>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF THE COMPANY FOR THE YEAR ENDED DECEMBER 31, 2020 COMPARED TO
YEAR ENDED DECEMBER 31, 2019</b></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">In addition to net income, the key financial indicators
that the Company reviews to monitor its business are revenues, model costs, operating expenses and cash flows.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">The Company analyzes revenue by reviewing the mix
of revenues generated by the different boards, by geographic locations and from significant clients.&nbsp;Wilhelmina&#8217;s primary
sources of revenue include: (i) revenues from principal relationships where the gross amount billed to the client is recorded as
revenue when earned and collectability is reasonably assured; and (ii) separate service charges, paid by clients in addition to
the booking fees, which are calculated as a percentage of the models&#8217; booking fees and are recorded as revenues when earned
and collectability is reasonably assured. See &#8220;Critical Accounting Policies - Revenue Recognition.&#8221;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">Wilhelmina provides professional services. Therefore,
salary and service costs represent the largest part of the Company&#8217;s operating expenses.&nbsp;Salary and service costs are
comprised of payroll and related costs and travel, meals and entertainment (&#8220;T&amp;E&#8221;) to deliver the Company&#8217;s
services and to enable new business development activities.</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0"><b>Analysis of Consolidated Statements of Operations</b></p>
