    <td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left">$</td><td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: right">629</td><td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left">&nbsp;</td><td style="font-size: 10pt; padding-bottom: 1pt">&nbsp;</td>
    <td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left">$</td><td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: right">7,547</td><td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left">&nbsp;</td></tr>
</table></div>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0"></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0; text-indent: 0.5in">In March 2020 and December 2019, the Company determined
there were triggering events, primarily caused by a sustained decrease in the Company&#8217;s stock price. The results of the goodwill
impairment tests indicated that the carrying values exceeded the estimated fair values. Thus, during March 2020 and December 2019,
the Company recorded impairment charges of $0.8 million and $4.8 million, respectively, related to its goodwill. Further declines
in the Company&#8217;s stock price could result in additional goodwill impairment charges.</p></div><p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0; text-indent: 0.5in"></p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="text-align: center; border-bottom: Black 4pt solid; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0">F-19</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0; text-indent: 228pt">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left; margin: 0 0 12pt"></p>


</body></html>

<P STYLE="font-size: 10pt; text-align: center; margin: 0">CERTIFICATION OF THE PRINCIPAL EXECUTIVE OFFICER</P>

<P STYLE="font-size: 10pt; text-align: center; margin: 0">&nbsp;</P>

<P STYLE="font-size: 10pt; text-align: center; margin: 0">PURSUANT TO SECTION 906 OF THE SARBANES-OXLEY ACT OF 2002</P>

<P STYLE="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0">&nbsp;</P>

<P STYLE="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">In connection with the annual report of Wilhelmina International, Inc.
(the &ldquo;Company&rdquo;) on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2020 as filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission
on the date hereof (the &ldquo;Report&rdquo;), I, Mark E. Schwarz, Executive Chairman of the Company, certify, pursuant to 18 U.S.C.
Section 1350, as adopted pursuant to Section 906 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, that, to my knowledge:</P>

<P STYLE="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">&nbsp;</P>

Act of 1934, as amended; and</TD></TR></TABLE>

<P STYLE="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0 0 0 0.5in">&nbsp;</P>

<TABLE CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%" STYLE="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"><TR STYLE="vertical-align: top">

condition and results of operations of the Company.</TD></TR></TABLE>

<P STYLE="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"></P>

<P STYLE="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"><B>&nbsp;</B></P>

<P STYLE="font-size: 10pt; text-align: center; margin: 0">CERTIFICATION OF THE PRINCIPAL FINANCIAL OFFICER</P>

<P STYLE="font-size: 10pt; text-align: center; margin: 0">&nbsp;</P>

<P STYLE="font-size: 10pt; text-align: center; margin: 0">PURSUANT TO SECTION 906 OF THE SARBANES-OXLEY ACT OF 2002</P>

<P STYLE="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0">&nbsp;</P>

<P STYLE="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0">In connection with the annual report of Wilhelmina International, Inc.
(the &ldquo;Company&rdquo;) on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2020 as filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission
on the date hereof (the &ldquo;Report&rdquo;), I, James A. McCarthy, Chief Financial Officer of the Company, certify, pursuant
to 18 U.S.C. Section 1350, as adopted pursuant to Section 906 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, that, to my knowledge:</P>

<P STYLE="font-size: 10pt; margin: 0">&nbsp;</P>

<TD STYLE="width: 0.25in"></TD><TD STYLE="width: 0.25in">1.</TD><TD STYLE="text-align: justify">The Report fully complies with the requirements of Section 13(a) or 15(d) of the Securities Exchange
Act of 1934, as amended; and</TD></TR></TABLE>

<P STYLE="font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0 0 0 0.5in">&nbsp;</P>

  <us-gaap:BasisOfAccounting contextRef="d_2020-01-01_2020-12-31" id="s1783158">&lt;div style="display: inline; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt"&gt;&lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-weight: bold;"&gt;Note &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;1.&lt;/div&gt;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Business Activity&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic;"&gt;Overview&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"&gt;The primary business of Wilhelmina is fashion model management. These business operations are headquartered in New York City.&amp;nbsp;The Company's predecessor was founded in &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;1967&lt;/div&gt; by Wilhelmina Cooper, a renowned fashion model, and became &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;one&lt;/div&gt; of the oldest, best known&amp;nbsp;and largest fashion model management companies in the world.&amp;nbsp;Since its founding, Wilhelmina has grown to include operations located in Los Angeles, Miami, Chicago, and London, as well as a network of licensees.&amp;nbsp;Wilhelmina provides traditional, full-service fashion model and talent management services, specializing in the representation and management of models, entertainers, athletes and other talent, to various clients, including retailers, designers, advertising agencies, print and electronic media and catalog companies.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</us-gaap:BasisOfAccounting>

  <us-gaap:CashAndCashEquivalentsAtCarryingValue contextRef="i_2019-12-31" decimals="-3" id="c70808324" unitRef="iso4217-usd">6993000</us-gaap:CashAndCashEquivalentsAtCarryingValue>

  <us-gaap:CashFDICInsuredAmount contextRef="i_2020-12-31" decimals="-3" id="c70808650" unitRef="iso4217-usd">250000</us-gaap:CashFDICInsuredAmount>
  <us-gaap:CashUninsuredAmount contextRef="i_2020-12-31" decimals="-3" id="c70808651" unitRef="iso4217-usd">2400000</us-gaap:CashUninsuredAmount>
  <us-gaap:CommitmentsAndContingenciesDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="d_2020-01-01_2020-12-31" id="s1783168">&lt;div style="display: inline; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt"&gt;&lt;div style=" margin: 0; font-size: 10pt"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-weight: bold;"&gt;Note &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;6.&lt;/div&gt;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Commitments and Contingencies&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0 0 0pt"&gt;On &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; October 24, 2013, &lt;/div&gt;a putative class action lawsuit was brought against the Company by former Wilhelmina model Alex Shanklin and others, including Louisa Raske, Carina Vretman, Grecia Palomares and Michelle Griffin Trotter (the &amp;#x201c;Shanklin Litigation&amp;#x201d;), in New York State Supreme Court (New York County)&amp;nbsp;by the same lead&amp;nbsp;counsel who represented plaintiffs in a prior, now-dismissed action brought by Louisa Raske (the &amp;#x201c;Raske Litigation&amp;#x201d;).&amp;nbsp; The claims in the Shanklin Litigation initially included breach of contract and unjust enrichment allegations arising out of matters similar to the Raske Litigation, such as the handling and reporting of funds on behalf&amp;nbsp;of models and the use of model images.&amp;nbsp; Other parties&amp;nbsp;named as defendants in the Shanklin Litigation include other model management companies, advertising firms, and certain advertisers.&amp;nbsp; On &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; January 6, 2014, &lt;/div&gt;the Company moved to dismiss the Amended Complaint in the Shanklin Litigation for failure to state a claim upon which relief can be granted and other grounds, and other defendants also filed motions to dismiss.&amp;nbsp; On &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; August 11, 2014, &lt;/div&gt;the court denied the motion to dismiss as to Wilhelmina and other of the model management defendants.&amp;nbsp; Separately, on &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; March 3, 2014, &lt;/div&gt;the judge assigned to the Shanklin Litigation wrote the Office of the New York Attorney General bringing the case to&amp;nbsp;its attention, generally describing the claims asserted therein against the model management defendants, and stating that the case &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; &amp;#x201c;may &lt;/div&gt;involve matters in the public interest.&amp;#x201d;&amp;nbsp;The judge's letter also enclosed a copy of his decision in the Raske Litigation, which dismissed that case.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" margin: 0 0 0pt; font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"&gt;Plaintiffs retained substitute counsel, who filed a Second and then Third Amended Complaint.&amp;nbsp;Plaintiffs' Third Amended Complaint asserts causes of action for alleged breaches of the plaintiffs' management contracts with the defendants, conversion, breach of the duty of good faith and fair dealing, and unjust enrichment.&amp;nbsp; The Third Amended Complaint also alleges that the plaintiff models were at all relevant times employees, and &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; independent contractors, of the model management defendants, and that defendants violated the New York Labor Law in several respects, including, among other things, by allegedly failing to pay the models the minimum wages and overtime pay required thereunder, &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; maintaining accurate payroll records, and &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; providing plaintiffs with full explanations of how their wages and deductions therefrom were computed.&amp;nbsp; The Third Amended Complaint seeks certification of the action as a class action, damages in an amount to be determined at trial, plus interest, costs, attorneys' fees, and such other relief as the court deems proper.&amp;nbsp; On &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; October 6, 2015, &lt;/div&gt;Wilhelmina filed a motion to dismiss as to most of the plaintiffs' claims.&amp;nbsp; The Court entered a decision granting in part and denying in part Wilhelmina's motion to dismiss on &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; May 26, 2017.&amp;nbsp; &lt;/div&gt;The Court (i) dismissed &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;three&lt;/div&gt; of the &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;five&lt;/div&gt; New York Labor Law causes of action, along with the conversion, breach of the duty of good faith and fair dealing and unjust enrichment causes of action, in their entirety, and (ii) permitted only the breach of contract causes of action, and some plaintiffs' remaining &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;two&lt;/div&gt; New York Labor Law causes of action to continue, within a limited time frame.&amp;nbsp; The plaintiffs&amp;nbsp;and Wilhelmina&amp;nbsp;each appealed, and the decision was affirmed on &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; May 24, 2018.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;On &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; August 16, 2017,&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;Wilhelmina timely filed its Answer to the Third Amended Complaint.&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" margin: 0; font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"&gt;On &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; June 6, 2016, &lt;/div&gt;another putative class action lawsuit was brought against the Company by former Wilhelmina model Shawn Pressley and others, including Roberta Little (the &amp;#x201c;Pressley Litigation&amp;#x201d;), in New York State Supreme Court (New York County) by the same counsel representing the plaintiffs in the Shanklin Litigation, and asserting identical, although more recent, claims as those in the Shanklin Litigation.&amp;nbsp; The Amended Complaint, asserting essentially the same types of claims as in the Shanklin action, was filed on &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; August 16, 2017.&amp;nbsp; &lt;/div&gt;Wilhelmina filed a motion to dismiss the Amended Complaint on &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; September 29, 2017, &lt;/div&gt;which was granted in part and denied in part on &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; May 10, 2018. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;Some New York Labor Law and contract claims remain in the case.&amp;nbsp; Pressley has withdrawn from the case, leaving Roberta Little as the sole remaining named plaintiff in the Pressley Litigation. &amp;nbsp;On &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; July 12, 2019, &lt;/div&gt;the Company filed its Answer and Counterclaim against Little.&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" margin: 0; font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"&gt;On &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; May 1, 2019, &lt;/div&gt;the Plaintiffs in the Shanklin Litigation (except Raske) and the Pressley Litigation filed motions for class certification on their contract claims and the remaining New York Labor Law Claims. On &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; July 12, 2019, &lt;/div&gt;Wilhelmina filed its opposition to the motions for class certification and filed a cross-motion for summary judgment against Shanklin, Vretman, Palomares, Trotter and Little, and a motion for summary judgment against Raske.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" margin: 0; font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0 0 0pt"&gt;By Order Dated &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; May 8, 2020 (&lt;/div&gt;the &amp;#x201c;Class Certification Order&amp;#x201d;), the Court denied class certification in the Pressley case, denied class certification with respect to the breach of contract and alleged unpaid usage claims, granted class certification as to the New York Labor Law causes of action asserted by Vretman, Palomares and Trotter, and declined to rule on Wilhelmina's motions for summary judgment, denying them without prejudice to be re-filed at a later date. On &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; June 12, 2020, &lt;/div&gt;the Plaintiffs in both the Shanklin and Pressley actions filed Notices of Appeal to the Appellate Division, First Department, from those portions of the Class Certification Order on which Wilhelmina prevailed. On &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; June 22, 2020, &lt;/div&gt;Wilhelmina filed Notices of Cross-Appeal from those portions of the Class Certification order that granted class Certification and denied summary judgment. The Court has directed the parties to non-binding mediation and that process is underway.&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" margin: 0 0 0pt; font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0 0 0pt"&gt;The Company believes the claims asserted in the Shanklin Litigation and Pressley Litigation are without merit and intends to continue to vigorously defend the actions.&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" margin: 0 0 0pt; font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;   &lt;!-- Field: /Page --&gt; &lt;div style=" margin: 0 0 0pt; font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;In addition to the legal proceedings disclosed herein, the Company is also engaged in various legal proceedings that are routine in nature and incidental to its business. &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;None&lt;/div&gt; of these routine proceedings, either individually or in the aggregate, are believed likely, in the Company's opinion, to have a material adverse effect on its consolidated financial position or its results of operations.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</us-gaap:CommitmentsAndContingenciesDisclosureTextBlock>

  <us-gaap:ConcentrationRiskCreditRisk contextRef="d_2020-01-01_2020-12-31" id="c70809861">&lt;div style="display: inline; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt"&gt;&lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic;"&gt;Concentrations of Credit Risk&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"&gt;The balance sheet items that potentially subject the Company to concentrations of credit risk are primarily cash and cash equivalents and accounts receivable.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The Company maintains its cash balances in several different financial institutions in New York, Los Angeles, Miami, and London. Balances in accounts other than &amp;#x201c;noninterest-bearing transaction accounts&amp;#x201d; are insured up to Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (&amp;#x201c;FDIC&amp;#x201d;) limits of &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$250&lt;/div&gt; thousand per institution.&amp;nbsp;At &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; December 31, 2020, &lt;/div&gt;the Company had cash balances in excess of FDIC insurance coverage of approximately &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$2.4&lt;/div&gt; million. Balances in London accounts are covered by Financial Services Compensation Scheme (&amp;#x201c;FSCS&amp;#x201d;) limits of &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;&amp;pound;75&lt;/div&gt; thousand or approximately &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$0.1&lt;/div&gt; million per institution. At &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; December 31, 2020, &lt;/div&gt;the Company had cash balances in excess of FSCS coverage of approximately &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$2.7&lt;/div&gt; million. Concentrations of credit risk with accounts receivable are mitigated by the Company's large number of clients and their dispersion across different industries and geographical areas.&amp;nbsp;The Company performs ongoing credit evaluations of its clients and maintains an allowance for doubtful accounts based upon the expected collectability of all accounts receivable.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</us-gaap:ConcentrationRiskCreditRisk>
  <us-gaap:ConsolidationPolicyTextBlock contextRef="d_2020-01-01_2020-12-31" id="c70809856">&lt;div style="display: inline; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt"&gt;&lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic;"&gt;Principles of Consolidation and Basis of Presentation&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"&gt;The financial statements include the consolidated accounts of Wilhelmina and its wholly owned subsidiaries. All significant inter-company accounts and transactions have been eliminated in consolidation. Certain prior year amounts have been reclassified to conform to current year presentation.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</us-gaap:ConsolidationPolicyTextBlock>

  <us-gaap:CurrentStateAndLocalTaxExpenseBenefit contextRef="d_2019-01-01_2019-12-31" decimals="-3" id="c70808905" unitRef="iso4217-usd">30000</us-gaap:CurrentStateAndLocalTaxExpenseBenefit>
  <us-gaap:DebtDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="d_2020-01-01_2020-12-31" id="s1783160">&lt;div style="display: inline; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt"&gt;&lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-weight: bold;"&gt;Note &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;3.&lt;/div&gt;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Debt&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"&gt;The Company has a credit agreement with Amegy Bank which provides a &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$4.0&lt;/div&gt; million revolving line of credit and previously provided up to a &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$3.0&lt;/div&gt; million term loan which could be drawn through &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; October 24, 2016. &lt;/div&gt;Amounts outstanding under the term loan reduce the availability under the revolving line of credit. The revolving line of credit is also subject to a borrowing base derived from &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;80%&lt;/div&gt; of eligible accounts receivable (as defined) and the Company's minimum net worth covenant. The revolving line of credit bears interest at prime plus &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;0.50%&lt;/div&gt; payable monthly. As of &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; December 31, 2020, &lt;/div&gt;the Company had a &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$0.2&lt;/div&gt; million irrevocable standby letter of credit outstanding under the revolving line of credit and had additional borrowing capacity of &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$1.7&lt;/div&gt; million. The revolving line of credit presently expires &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; October 24, 2022.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"&gt;On &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; August 16, 2016, &lt;/div&gt;the Company drew &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$2.7&lt;/div&gt; million of the term loan and used the proceeds to fund the purchase of shares of its common stock in a private transaction. The term loan bore interest at &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;4.5%&lt;/div&gt; per annum and was payable in monthly payments of interest only until &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; November, 2016, &lt;/div&gt;followed by &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;47&lt;/div&gt; equal monthly payments of principal and interest computed on a &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;60&lt;/div&gt;-month amortization schedule. A final &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$0.6&lt;/div&gt; million payment of principal and interest was paid on &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; October 28, 2020.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"&gt;On &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; July 16, 2018, &lt;/div&gt;the Company amended its credit agreement with Amegy Bank to provide for an additional term loan of up to &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$1.0&lt;/div&gt; million that could be drawn by the Company through &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; July 12, 2019, &lt;/div&gt;for the purpose of repurchases of its common stock. The additional term loan is evidenced by a promissory note bearing interest at &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;5.15%&lt;/div&gt; per annum and was payable in monthly installments of interest only through &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; July 12, 2019. &lt;/div&gt;Thereafter, the note is payable in monthly installments sufficient to fully amortize the outstanding principal balance in &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;60&lt;/div&gt; months with the balance of principal and accrued interest due on &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; July 12, 2023.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"&gt;Amounts outstanding under the additional term loan reduce the availability under the Company's revolving line of credit with Amegy Bank. On &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; August 1, 2018, &lt;/div&gt;the Company drew &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$0.7&lt;/div&gt; million of the additional term loan and used the proceeds to fund the purchase of &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;100,000&lt;/div&gt; shares of its common stock in a private transaction. On &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; December 12, 2018, &lt;/div&gt;the Company drew &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$0.3&lt;/div&gt; million of the additional term loan and used the proceeds to partially fund a purchase of &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;50,000&lt;/div&gt; shares of its common stock in a private transaction. As of &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; December 31, 2020, &lt;/div&gt;a total of &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$0.7&lt;/div&gt; million was outstanding on the term loan.&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0; background-color: white"&gt;Reduced outstanding accounts receivable available as collateral under the Company's credit agreement with Amegy Bank has limited access to additional financing. Net losses in recent periods have also impacted compliance with the financial covenants under the Amegy Bank credit agreement, further impeding the Company's ability to obtain additional financing. On &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; March 26, 2020, &lt;/div&gt;the Company entered into a Thirteenth Amendment to Credit Agreement (the &amp;#x201c;Thirteenth Amendment&amp;#x201d;) with Amegy Bank. The Thirteenth Amendment amended the minimum net worth covenant to require the Company to maintain tangible net worth (as defined therein) of &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$4.0&lt;/div&gt; million, determined on a quarterly basis. Under the Thirteenth Amendment, Amegy Bank also waived an existing default caused by the Company's failure to satisfy the previously required &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$20.0&lt;/div&gt; million minimum net worth covenant as of &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; December 31, 2019. &lt;/div&gt;On &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; May 12, 2020, &lt;/div&gt;the Company entered into a Fourteenth Amendment to Credit Agreement (the &amp;#x201c;Fourteenth Amendment&amp;#x201d;) with Amegy Bank. The Fourteenth Amendment amended the line of credit to reduce the maximum borrowing capacity to &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$3.0&lt;/div&gt; million. Under the Fourteenth Amendment, Amegy Bank also waived an existing default caused by the Company's failure to satisfy both the minimum fixed charge coverage ratio through &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; March 31, 2020 &lt;/div&gt;and minimum tangible net worth as of &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; March 31, 2020. &lt;/div&gt;The Company obtained waivers from Amegy Bank of its failures to satisfy the fixed charge coverage ratio, the minimum tangible net worth, and the borrowing base for the quarters ended &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; June 30, 2020 &lt;/div&gt;and &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; September 30, 2020. &lt;/div&gt;On &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; November 10, 2020, &lt;/div&gt;the Company entered into a Fifteenth Amendment to Credit Agreement (the &amp;#x201c;Fifteenth Amendment&amp;#x201d;) with Amegy Bank. The Fifteenth Amendment waived the minimum tangible net worth covenant until &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; December 31, 2021, &lt;/div&gt;after which a minimum tangible net worth of &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$1.5&lt;/div&gt; million will be required. The Fifteenth Amendment also revised the calculation of the fixed charge coverage ratio such that it will be tested at &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; December 31, 2020 &lt;/div&gt;based on the preceding &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;six&lt;/div&gt; month period, tested at &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; March 31, 2021 &lt;/div&gt;based on the preceding &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;nine&lt;/div&gt; month period, and tested at &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; June 30, 2021 &lt;/div&gt;and subsequent periods using a &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;twelve&lt;/div&gt; month rolling period.&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0; background-color: white"&gt;On &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; April 15, 2020, &lt;/div&gt;Wilhelmina International, Ltd. (the &amp;#x201c;Borrower&amp;#x201d;), a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Company, executed a Business Loan Agreement and a Promissory Note each dated &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; April 13, 2020 (&lt;/div&gt;collectively, the &amp;#x201c;Sub PPP Loan Documents&amp;#x201d;), with respect to a loan in the amount of &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$1.8&lt;/div&gt; million (the &amp;#x201c;Sub PPP Loan&amp;#x201d;) from Amegy Bank. The Sub PPP Loan was obtained pursuant to the PPP. The Sub PPP Loan originally matured on &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; April 13, 2022 &lt;/div&gt;and bears interest at a rate of &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;1.00%&lt;/div&gt; per annum. As allowed under the Paycheck Protection Flexibility Act, the Sub PPP Loan was extended to mature on &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; April 13, 2025 &lt;/div&gt;and is payable in &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;44&lt;/div&gt; equal monthly payments of &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$43&lt;/div&gt; thousand commencing in &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; August 2021.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0; background-color: white"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;   &lt;!-- Field: /Page --&gt; &lt;div style=" margin: 0; font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; background-color: white"&gt;On &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; April 18, 2020, &lt;/div&gt;the Company executed a Business Loan Agreement and a Promissory Note each dated &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; April 17, 2020 (&lt;/div&gt;collectively, the &amp;#x201c;Parent PPP Loan Documents&amp;#x201d;), with respect to a loan in the amount of &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$128&lt;/div&gt; thousand (the &amp;#x201c;Parent PPP Loan&amp;#x201d;) from Amegy Bank. The Parent PPP Loan was also obtained pursuant to the PPP. The Parent PPP Loan originally matured on &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; April 17, 2022 &lt;/div&gt;and bears interest at a rate of &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;1.00%&lt;/div&gt; per annum. As allowed under the Paycheck Protection Flexibility Act, the Parent PPP Loan was extended to mature on &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; April 17, 2025 &lt;/div&gt;and is payable in &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;44&lt;/div&gt; equal monthly payments of &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$3&lt;/div&gt; thousand commencing in &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; August 2021.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0; background-color: white"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0; background-color: white"&gt;Both the Sub PPP Loan and the Parent PPP Loan (collectively, the &amp;#x201c;PPP Loans&amp;#x201d;) &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; may &lt;/div&gt;be prepaid at any time prior to maturity with &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;no&lt;/div&gt; prepayment penalties. Both the Sub PPP Loan Documents and the Parent PPP Loan Documents contain various provisions related to the PPP, as well customary representations, warranties, covenants, events of default and other provisions. Neither of the PPP Loans is secured by either the Borrower or the Company, and both are guaranteed by the SBA. All or a portion of the PPP Loans &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; may &lt;/div&gt;be forgiven by the SBA upon application by the Borrower or the Company, respectively, accompanied by documentation of expenditures in accordance with the SBA requirements under the PPP. In the event all or any portion of the PPP Loans is forgiven, the amount forgiven is applied to outstanding principal, and would be recorded as income.&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0; background-color: white"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0; background-color: white"&gt;As of &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; December 31, 2020, &lt;/div&gt;a total of &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$2.0&lt;/div&gt; million was outstanding on the PPP Loans.&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0; background-color: white"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" margin: 0; font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; background-color: white"&gt;As of &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; December 31, 2020, &lt;/div&gt;future maturities of long term debt were as follows (in thousands):&lt;/div&gt;   <us-gaap:DisclosureOfCompensationRelatedCostsShareBasedPaymentsTextBlock contextRef="d_2020-01-01_2020-12-31" id="s1783175">&lt;div style="display: inline; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt"&gt;&lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-weight: bold;"&gt;Note &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;10.&lt;/div&gt;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Stock Options and Stock Purchase Warrants&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"&gt;During &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;2015,&lt;/div&gt; shareholders of the Company approved the &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;2015&lt;/div&gt; Incentive Plan which authorized the issuance of up to an &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;500,000&lt;/div&gt; shares of the common stock pursuant to stock options, restricted stock, stock appreciation rights and other equity incentives awarded to directors, officers, consultants, advisors and employees of the Company. Stock option awards under the &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;2015&lt;/div&gt; Incentive Plan are granted at the market value of the common stock on the date of grant, have vesting periods of &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;five&lt;/div&gt; years, and expire to the extent unexercised after &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;ten&lt;/div&gt; years.&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"&gt;Under the &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;2015&lt;/div&gt; Incentive Plan, &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;no&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt; stock option awards were granted during &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;2020&lt;/div&gt; or &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;2019.&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;No&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt; stock options were exercised during either &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;2020&lt;/div&gt; or &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;2019.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0"&gt;The following table shows a summary of stock option transactions under the &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;2015&lt;/div&gt; Incentive Plan during &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;2020&lt;/div&gt; and &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;2019:&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div&gt; &lt;table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: right"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;6.93&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;/tr&gt;  &lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; background-color: White"&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: right"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: right"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;/tr&gt;    &lt;/table&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; margin: 0; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" margin: 0; font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;Weighted average remaining contractual life was &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;5.83&lt;/div&gt; years at &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; December 31, 2020 &lt;/div&gt;and &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;6.61&lt;/div&gt; years at &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; December 31, 2019. &lt;/div&gt;The exercise price of all stock options was below the market value at both &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; December 31, 2020 &lt;/div&gt;and &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;2019.&lt;/div&gt; Therefore, there is &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;no&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt; intrinsic value at &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; December 31, 2020 &lt;/div&gt;and &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;2019.&lt;/div&gt; Total unrecognized compensation expense on options outstanding as of &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; December 31, 2020 &lt;/div&gt;was &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$8&lt;/div&gt; thousand. Options to purchase &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;42,000&lt;/div&gt; shares of common stock were exercisable as of &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; December 31, 2020.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;   &lt;!-- Field: /Page --&gt; &lt;div style=" margin: 0; font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;The Company estimates the fair value of each stock option granted on the date of grant using the Black-Scholes option pricing model. Expected volatilities are based on the historical volatility of Wilhelmina's and similar companies' common stock for a period equal to the expected term. The risk-free interest rates for periods within the contractual term of the options are based on rates for U.S. Treasury Notes with maturity dates corresponding to the options' expected lives on the dates of grant. Expected term is determined based on the option term of &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;ten&lt;/div&gt; years.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</us-gaap:DisclosureOfCompensationRelatedCostsShareBasedPaymentsTextBlock>

  <us-gaap:EmployeeServiceShareBasedCompensationNonvestedAwardsTotalCompensationCostNotYetRecognizedStockOptions contextRef="i_2020-12-31_PlanNameAxis-IncentivePlan2015Member" decimals="-3" id="c70809034" unitRef="iso4217-usd">8000</us-gaap:EmployeeServiceShareBasedCompensationNonvestedAwardsTotalCompensationCostNotYetRecognizedStockOptions>
  <us-gaap:FairValueMeasurementPolicyPolicyTextBlock contextRef="d_2020-01-01_2020-12-31" id="c70809868">&lt;div style="display: inline; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt"&gt;&lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic;"&gt;Fair Value Measurements&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"&gt;The Company has adopted the provisions of ASC &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;820,&lt;/div&gt; &amp;#x201c;Fair Value Measurements&amp;#x201d; (&amp;#x201c;ASC &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;820&amp;#x201d;&lt;/div&gt;), for financial assets and financial liabilities.&amp;nbsp;ASC &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;820&lt;/div&gt; defines fair value, establishes a framework for measuring fair value under GAAP, and expands disclosure about fair value measurements.&amp;nbsp;ASC &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;820&lt;/div&gt; applies to all financial instruments that are being measured and reported on a fair value basis.&amp;nbsp;ASC &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;820&lt;/div&gt; defines fair value as the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date.&amp;nbsp;ASC &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;820&lt;/div&gt; also establishes a fair value hierarchy that prioritizes the inputs used in valuation methodologies into the following &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;three&lt;/div&gt; levels:&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0; min-width: 700px;"&gt; &lt;tr style="vertical-align: top"&gt; &lt;td style="width: 0"&gt;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;td style="width: 27pt"&gt;&amp;#x2022;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;Level &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;1&lt;/div&gt; Inputs-Unadjusted: quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.&lt;/td&gt; &lt;/tr&gt; &lt;/table&gt; &lt;table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0; min-width: 700px;"&gt; &lt;tr style="vertical-align: top"&gt; &lt;td style="width: 0"&gt;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;td style="width: 27pt"&gt;&amp;#x2022;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;Level &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;2&lt;/div&gt; Inputs-Observable: inputs other than Level &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;1&lt;/div&gt; prices, such as quoted prices for similar assets or liabilities; quoted prices in markets that are &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; active; or other inputs that are observable or can be corroborated by observable market data for substantially the full term of the assets or liabilities.&lt;/td&gt; &lt;/tr&gt; &lt;/table&gt; &lt;table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0; min-width: 700px;"&gt; &lt;tr style="vertical-align: top"&gt; &lt;td style="width: 0"&gt;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;td style="width: 27pt"&gt;&amp;#x2022;&lt;/td&gt; &lt;td style="text-align: justify"&gt;Level &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;3&lt;/div&gt; Inputs-Unobservable: inputs that are supported by little or &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;no&lt;/div&gt; market activity and that are significant to the fair value of the assets or liabilities.&amp;nbsp;Level &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;3&lt;/div&gt; assets and liabilities include financial instruments whose value is determined using pricing models, discounted&amp;nbsp;cash flow methodologies, or other valuation techniques, as well as instruments for which the determination of fair value requires significant management judgment or estimation.&lt;/td&gt; &lt;/tr&gt; &lt;/table&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</us-gaap:FairValueMeasurementPolicyPolicyTextBlock>

  <us-gaap:Goodwill contextRef="i_2020-12-31_ReportingUnitAxis-LondonReportingUnitMember" decimals="-3" id="c70809082" unitRef="iso4217-usd">629000</us-gaap:Goodwill>
  <us-gaap:Goodwill contextRef="i_2020-12-31" decimals="-3" id="c70809083" unitRef="iso4217-usd">7547000</us-gaap:Goodwill>
  <us-gaap:GoodwillAndIntangibleAssetsGoodwillPolicy contextRef="d_2020-01-01_2020-12-31" id="c70809863">&lt;div style="display: inline; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt"&gt;&lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic;"&gt;Goodwill and Intangible Assets&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"&gt;Goodwill represents the excess of the purchase price in a business combination over the fair value of the tangible and intangible assets acquired and the liabilities assumed. The Company's intangible assets other than goodwill consist of trademarks and trade name.&amp;nbsp; Goodwill and intangible assets with indefinite lives are &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; subject to amortization, but rather to an annual assessment of impairment by applying a fair-value based test.&amp;nbsp;A significant amount of judgment is required in estimating fair value and performing goodwill impairment tests.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"&gt;At least annually, the Company assesses whether the carrying value of its goodwill and intangible assets exceeds their fair value and, if necessary, records an impairment loss equal to any such excess. The Company sometimes utilizes an independent valuation specialist to assist with the determination of fair value. Each interim reporting period, the Company assesses whether events or circumstances have occurred which indicate that the carrying amount of an intangible asset exceeds its fair value.&amp;nbsp;If the carrying amount of the intangible asset exceeds its fair value, an asset impairment charge will be recognized in an amount equal to that excess.&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"&gt;The process of estimating the fair value of goodwill is subjective and requires the Company to make estimates that &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; may &lt;/div&gt;significantly impact the outcome of the analysis. A qualitative assessment considers events and circumstances such as macroeconomic conditions, industry and market conditions, cost factors, and overall financial performance. If after performing this assessment, the Company concludes it is more likely than &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; that the fair value of the reporting unit is less than its carrying amount, then the Company performs the quantitative test.&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"&gt;Under the quantitative test, a goodwill impairment is identified by comparing the fair value to the carrying amount, including goodwill. If the carrying amount exceeds the fair value, goodwill is considered impaired and an impairment charge is recognized in an amount equal to the excess, &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; to exceed the carrying amount of goodwill.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</us-gaap:GoodwillAndIntangibleAssetsGoodwillPolicy>

margin: 0"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-weight: bold;"&gt;Note &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;12.&lt;/div&gt;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Goodwill &lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"&gt;Changes to the carrying amount of Goodwill are as follows (in thousands):&lt;/div&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;/tr&gt;    &lt;/table&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0"&gt;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;In &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; March 2020 &lt;/div&gt;and &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; December 2019, &lt;/div&gt;the Company determined there were triggering events, primarily caused by a sustained decrease in the Company's stock price. The results of the goodwill impairment tests indicated that the carrying values exceeded the estimated fair values. Thus, during &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; March 2020 &lt;/div&gt;and &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; December 2019, &lt;/div&gt;the Company recorded impairment charges of &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$0.8&lt;/div&gt; million and &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$4.8&lt;/div&gt; million, respectively, related to its goodwill. Further declines in the Company's stock price could result in additional goodwill impairment charges.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</us-gaap:GoodwillDisclosureTextBlock>
  <us-gaap:GoodwillImpairmentLoss contextRef="d_2020-01-01_2020-12-31" decimals="-5" id="c70808872" unitRef="iso4217-usd">800000</us-gaap:GoodwillImpairmentLoss>
  <us-gaap:GoodwillImpairmentLoss contextRef="d_2019-01-01_2019-12-31" decimals="-3" id="c70808880" unitRef="iso4217-usd">4845000</us-gaap:GoodwillImpairmentLoss>

 &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: right"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; text-align: left"&gt;)&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;/tr&gt;  &lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; background-color: rgb(204,238,255)"&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left; padding-bottom: 1pt"&gt;Valuation allowance&lt;/td&gt; text-align: left"&gt;)&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; padding-bottom: 1pt"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: right"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;(340&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;)&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;/tr&gt;  &lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; background-color: White"&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left; padding-bottom: 1pt"&gt;Total income tax expense&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; padding-bottom: 1pt"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: right"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;(902&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;)&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; padding-bottom: 1pt"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: right"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;(400&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;)&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;/tr&gt;  &lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; background-color: rgb(204,238,255)"&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left; padding-bottom: 1pt"&gt;Effective tax rate&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; padding-bottom: 1pt"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: right"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;22.3&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;%&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; padding-bottom: 1pt"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: right"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;9.1&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;%&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;/tr&gt;    &lt;/table&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;The Company reported income tax expense of &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$0.9&lt;/div&gt; million for &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;2020&lt;/div&gt; despite a pre-tax loss. The expense was primarily due to a &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$1.5&lt;/div&gt; million valuation allowance recorded against deferred tax assets. The valuation allowance was the result of management's assessment as of &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; December 31, 2020 &lt;/div&gt;that it was &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; more likely than &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; that the benefit of the Company's deferred tax assets would be realized primarily due to the impact of the COVID-&lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;19&lt;/div&gt; pandemic on its business. Income tax expense for &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;2020&lt;/div&gt; was also impacted by foreign taxes in the United Kingdom related to the Company's London office that are &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; deductible for U.S. income tax purposes. In addition, the &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$0.8&lt;/div&gt; million goodwill impairment recorded in &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;2020&lt;/div&gt; resulted in only a &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$0.1&lt;/div&gt; million tax benefit due to certain permanent tax differences.&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;The Company reported income tax expense of &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$0.4&lt;/div&gt; million for &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;2019&lt;/div&gt; despite a pre-tax loss due primarily to a &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$0.3&lt;/div&gt; million valuation allowance recorded against deferred tax assets related to forfeited stock options. Income tax expense for &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;2019&lt;/div&gt; was also impacted by foreign taxes in the United Kingdom related to the Company's London office that are &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; deductible for U.S. income tax purposes. In addition, the &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$4.8&lt;/div&gt; million goodwill impairment recorded in &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;2019&lt;/div&gt; resulted in only a &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$0.3&lt;/div&gt; million tax benefit due to certain permanent tax differences.&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" margin: 0; font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0"&gt;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" margin: 0; font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;   &lt;!-- Field: /Page --&gt; &lt;div style=" margin: 0; font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;The following table shows the tax effect of significant temporary differences, which comprise the deferred tax asset and liability (in thousands):&lt;/div&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; padding-bottom: 1pt"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: right"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;(1,486&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;)&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; padding-bottom: 1pt"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: right"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;(340&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: right"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: right"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt; background-color: rgb(204,238,255)"&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left; padding-left: 0.25in"&gt;Property and equipment&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; background-color: White"&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left; padding-left: 0.25in"&gt;Right of use asset&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; background-color: rgb(204,238,255)"&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left; padding-left: 0.25in"&gt;Intangible assets-brand name&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: right"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;(1,197&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;)&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: right"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;(1,079&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;)&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;/tr&gt;  &lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; background-color: White"&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; padding-left: 0.25in"&gt;Goodwill&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: right"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;(288&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;)&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: right"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;(257&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;)&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;/tr&gt;  &lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; background-color: rgb(204,238,255)"&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left; padding-left: 0.25in"&gt;Other intangible assets&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; padding-bottom: 1pt"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: right"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;(451&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;)&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; padding-bottom: 1pt"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: right"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;(338&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;)&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;/tr&gt;  &lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; background-color: White"&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left; padding-bottom: 1pt; padding-left: 0.25in"&gt;Total deferred income tax liability&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; padding-bottom: 1pt"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: right"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;(2,231&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;)&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; padding-bottom: 1pt"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: right"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;(2,458&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;)&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;/tr&gt;  &lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; background-color: rgb(204,238,255)"&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; text-align: left; padding-left: 0.25in"&gt;Net deferred tax liability&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; padding-bottom: 1pt"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: right"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;(1,449&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;)&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="font-size: 10pt; padding-bottom: 1pt"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: right"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;(725&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;td style="border-bottom: Black 1pt solid; font-size: 10pt; text-align: left"&gt;)&lt;/td&gt;  &lt;/tr&gt;    &lt;/table&gt; &lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0 0 0pt"&gt;The presentation of net deferred tax assets and liabilities are presented as noncurrent within the Company's Consolidated Balance Sheets. Deferred income tax balances reflect the effects of temporary differences between the carrying amounts of assets and liabilities and their tax bases and are stated at enacted tax rates expected to be in effect when the taxes are actually paid or recovered. The Company recognizes a valuation allowance for deferred tax assets when it is more likely than &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; that these assets will &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; be realized. In making this determination, all positive and negative evidence is considered, including future reversals of existing taxable temporary differences, tax planning strategies, future taxable income, and taxable income in prior carryback years.&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" margin: 0 0 0pt; font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0 0 0pt"&gt;At &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; December 31, 2020 &lt;/div&gt;and &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; December 31, 2019, &lt;/div&gt;the Company has &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$4.3&lt;/div&gt; million and &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$0.5&lt;/div&gt; million, respectively, of federal net operating loss carryforwards, of which &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$0.5&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt; million expires in &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;2037&lt;/div&gt; and the remainder do &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; expire. Additionally, the Company has &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;$0.5&lt;/div&gt; million of U.S. federal foreign tax credit carryforwards, which expire between &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;2023&lt;/div&gt; and &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;2029.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" margin: 0 0 0pt; font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" margin: 0 0 0pt; font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;The Company does &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;not&lt;/div&gt; believe that it had any significant uncertain tax positions at &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; December 31, 2020 &lt;/div&gt;and &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; December 31, 2019, &lt;/div&gt;nor is this expected to change within the next &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;twelve&lt;/div&gt; months due to the settlement and expiration of statutes of limitation.&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" margin: 0 0 0pt; font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" margin: 0 0 0pt; font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;The U.S. Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (the &amp;#x201c;Tax Act&amp;#x201d;) was enacted on &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; December 22, 2017 &lt;/div&gt;and introduced significant changes to U.S. income tax law. Effective in &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;2018,&lt;/div&gt; the Tax Act reduced the U.S. statutory tax rate from &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;35%&lt;/div&gt; to &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;21%&lt;/div&gt; and created new taxes on certain foreign-sourced earnings and certain related-party payments, which are referred to as the global intangible low-taxed income tax and base erosion tax, respectively. In &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; January 2018, &lt;/div&gt;the FASB released guidance on the accounting for tax on the global intangible low-taxed income (&amp;#x201c;GILTI&amp;#x201d;) provisions of the Tax Act. The GILTI provisions impose a tax on foreign income in excess of a deemed return on tangible assets of foreign corporations. The Company elected to treat any potential GILTI inclusions as a period cost.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</us-gaap:IncomeTaxDisclosureTextBlock>
  <us-gaap:IncomeTaxExpenseBenefit contextRef="d_2020-01-01_2020-12-31" decimals="-3" id="c70808864" unitRef="iso4217-usd">902000</us-gaap:IncomeTaxExpenseBenefit>
  <us-gaap:IncomeTaxExpenseBenefit contextRef="d_2019-01-01_2019-12-31" decimals="-5" id="c70808875" unitRef="iso4217-usd">400000</us-gaap:IncomeTaxExpenseBenefit>
  <us-gaap:IncomeTaxPolicyTextBlock contextRef="d_2020-01-01_2020-12-31" id="c70809866">&lt;div style="display: inline; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-family: times new roman; font-size: 10pt"&gt;&lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; margin: 0"&gt;&lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic;"&gt;Income Taxes&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"&gt;Income taxes are accounted for under the asset and liability method. Deferred income tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the future tax consequences attributable to differences between the financial statement carrying amounts of existing assets and liabilities and their respective tax base and operating loss and tax credit carryforwards. Deferred income tax assets and liabilities are measured using enacted tax rates expected to apply to taxable income in the years in which those temporary differences are expected to be recovered or settled. The effect on deferred income tax assets and liabilities of a change in tax rates is recognized in income in the period that includes the enactment date. The Company continually assesses the need for a tax valuation allowance based on all available information.&lt;/div&gt; &lt;div style=" font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in; margin: 0"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt; &lt;!-- Field: /Page --&gt; &lt;div style=" margin: 0; font-size: 10pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;Accounting for uncertainty in income taxes recognized in an enterprise's financial statements requires a recognition threshold and measurement attribute for the financial statement recognition and measurement of a tax position taken or expected to be taken in a tax return.&amp;nbsp;Also, consideration should be given to de-recognition, classification, interest and penalties, accounting in interim periods, disclosure and transition.&amp;nbsp;Tax positions are subject to change in the future, as a number of years &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; may &lt;/div&gt;elapse before a particular matter for which an established reserve is audited and finally resolved.&amp;nbsp;Federal tax returns for tax years &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;2017&lt;/div&gt; through &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt;2019&lt;/div&gt; remained open for examination as of &lt;div style="display: inline; font-style: italic; font: inherit;"&gt; December 31, 2020.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;</us-gaap:IncomeTaxPolicyTextBlock>
